revision.text:
{{other uses}} [[File:Soup with meatballs-01.jpg|thumb|''[[Hochzeitssuppe]]'', German traditional wedding soup with meatballs]] [[File:I'm 51 and have never made my own meatballs. Till tonight. Had some good ground beef from the TRU Meat Store. (15795383467).jpg|thumb|Raw meatballs]] [[File:Gehaktballetjes.jpg|thumb|Meatballs being cooked]] A '''meatball''' is [[ground meat]] rolled into a small [[ball]], sometimes along with other ingredients, such as [[bread crumbs]], minced [[onion]], [[egg (food)|eggs]], [[butter]], and seasoning.<ref name="Smithsonian">{{cite web | title = Is Spaghetti and Meatballs Italian? | first =Shaylyn | last = Esposito | publisher = Sithsonian.com | date = 6 June 2013 | url = http://www.smithsonianmag.com/arts-culture/is-spaghetti-and-meatballs-italian-94819690/?no-ist | accessdate = 14 April 2015}}</ref>
Meatballs are cooked by [[frying]], [[baking]], [[steaming]], or [[braising]] in sauce.
There are many types of meatballs using different types of [[meats]] and [[spices]]. The term is sometimes extended to meatless versions based on vegetables or fish; the latter are commonly known as [[fishball]]s.
== History ==
The [[Chinese cuisine|Chinese recipe]] "Four Joy Meatballs" (四喜丸子—''Sì xǐ wánzi'') is derived from [[Shandong cuisine]], which originated in the native cooking styles of [[Shandong]]. Its history dates back to the [[Qin dynasty]] (221 BC to 207 BC).<ref>{{cite web| title = Lu Cuisine | publisher = A bite of China | url = https://sites.google.com/site/chinasbite/home/lu-cusine | accessdate = 14 April 2015 }}</ref>{{Self-published source|date=September 2017}}
The [[Ancient Rome|ancient Roman]] cookbook ''[[Apicius]]'' included many meatball-type recipes.<ref>Sally Grainger, ''Cooking Apicius: Roman Recipes for Today'', Prospect Books, 2006, {{ISBN|1-903018-44-7}}, p. 17-18</ref>
Early recipes included in some of the earliest known [[Arab cuisine|Arabic cookbooks]] generally feature seasoned lamb rolled into orange-sized balls and glazed with egg yolk and sometimes [[saffron]]. This method was taken to the West and is referred to as gilding. Many regional variations exist, notable among them the unusually large [[Tabriz#Cuisine|''kufteh Tabrizi'']], having an average diameter of {{convert|20|cm}}.<ref>[[The Oxford Companion to Food]], ''s.v.'' kofta</ref>
''[[Poume d'oranges]]'' is a gilded meatball dish from the [[Middle Ages]].<ref>{{cite book | last=Adamson | first=M.W. | title=Regional Cuisines of Medieval Europe: A Book of Essays | publisher=Taylor & Francis | series=Garland Medieval Casebooks | year=2013 | isbn=978-1-135-30868-1 | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=VelSAQAAQBAJ&pg=PA27 | access-date=June 15, 2017 | page=27}}</ref>
== Various cultures == Various recipes of meatballs can be found across Europe and Asia. From [[Iberia]] and [[Sweden]] to [[India]], there is a large variety of meatballs in the [[kofta]] family.<ref>[[Alan Davidson (food writer)|Alan Davidson]], ed., ''[[The Oxford Companion to Food]]'', ''s.v.'' kofta</ref>
=== Europe === [[File:Tatarsko kufte.JPG|thumb|[[Bulgaria]]n big meatball, ''tatarsko kufte'']] [[File:Frikadeller.jpg|thumb|A freshly made batch of Danish meatballs (''[[frikadeller]]'')]] [[File:koettbullar stockholm2006.jpg|thumb|Meatballs served in Swedish and Finnish style with [[mashed potato]]es, [[Brown sauce (meat stock based)|brown sauce]], [[lingonberry jam]] and pickled cucumber]] [[File:04848 Meatballs Klopsy, PL 2011.JPG|thumb|''Klopsy'' with potato purée from Poland]] [[File:Inegöl köfte.jpg|thumb|[[İnegöl meatballs]] from Turkey.]] *[[Albanian cuisine|Albanian]] fried meatballs (''qofte të fërguara'') include [[feta cheese]]. *[[Armenian cuisine|Armenian]] stewed meatballs/meatball and vegetable stew (''kufte rize'') is a classic dish often poured over rice for consumption. *In [[Austria]], fried meatballs are called ''Fleischlaibchen'' or ''Fleischlaberl''. *In [[Belgium]], meatballs are called ''ballekes'' or ''bouletten'' in [[Flanders]] and are usually made of a mixture of beef and pork with bread crumbs and sliced onions. Many other variations exist, including different kinds of meat and chopped vegetables. *In [[Bosnian cuisine|Bosnian]], meatballs are called ''ćufte'' and are typically made from ground beef and served with mashed potatoes. *In [[Bulgaria]], meatballs are called ''kyufte'' and are typically made from ground beef or pork, or a mix of the two. They can be shallow fried or grilled and often contain diced onions and soaked bread. They are a very popular dish. *In [[Croatia]], meatballs are called polpete in the Dalmatian region or ćufte in the continental part. They are typically made with ground beef or a mixture of pork and beef and served with mashed potatoes or rice, often with tomato based sauce. *[[Danish cuisine|Danish]] meatballs are known as ''[[frikadeller]]'' and are typically fried. They are usually made out of ground [[pork]], veal, onions, eggs, salt, and pepper; these are formed into balls and flattened somewhat, so they are [[Frying pan|pan]] ready. However, the Danish cuisine also includes other versions, such as "Boller i Karry" (meatballs in curry sauce, typically served with rice), and the smaller meatballs used in soup with "Melboller" (Danish dumplings). *In [[Estonia]], meatballs are called ''lihapallid'' (literally "meatballs") and are similar to those of Finnish or Swedish cuisine. *In [[Finnish cuisine]], meatballs are called ''lihapullat'' (literally "meatbuns"). They are made with ground beef or a mix of ground beef and pork, or even with ground reindeer meat, mixed with breadcrumbs soaked in milk or [[viili]], beef stock and finely chopped onions or alternatively, [[French onion soup]] readymix. They are seasoned with [[white pepper]] and [[salt]]. Meatballs are traditionally served with gravy, boiled potatoes (or mashed potatoes), [[lingonberry jam]], and sometimes [[pickled cucumber]]. *In [[Alsace]], [[France]], meatballs are known as ''Fleischkiechele''. They are made of beef, pork, onions, bacon, eggs, and bread. They are served plain or with cream sauce.<ref>Wikipedia in French</ref> *In [[Germany]], meatballs are mostly known as ''Frikadelle'', ''Fleischküchle'', ''Fleischpflanzerl'', ''Bulette'' or ''Klopse''. A very famous variant of meatballs are ''[[Königsberger Klopse]]'', which contain [[anchovy]] or salted [[herring]], and are eaten with [[Caper#Culinary uses|caper sauce]]. *In [[Greece]], fried meatballs are called ''keftédes'' (κεφτέδες) and usually include within the mix of bread, onions, parsley and mint leaf.<ref name=CFVM>{{cite web|title=Κεφτέδες|url=http://foodmuseum.cs.ucy.ac.cy/web/guest/parsintages/civitem/1682|website=foodmuseum.cs.ucy.ac.cy|publisher=Cyprus Food Virtual Museum|accessdate=30 November 2015|language=Greek}}</ref> Stewed meatballs are called ''yuvarlákia'' (γιουβαρλάκια: from the [[Turkish language|Turkish]] word ''yuvarlak'', which means "round") and usually include small quantities of rice. *In [[Hungary]], as well as territories from neighbouring countries where Hungarian is spoken, a meatball is called ''fasírt'' {{IPA-hu|ˈfɒʃiːrt|}} or ''fasírozott'' {{IPA-hu|ˈfɒʃiːrozott|}} probably coming from Austrian German ''faschierte Laibchen''. It is a mixture of minced pork meat, minced onions, garlic, paprika, salt and breadcrumbs, deep fried in oil or pork fat and eaten with potatoes or [[főzelék]]. Also, the ''májgombóc'' {{IPA-hu|ˈmaːjɡomboːt͡s|}} (liver dumpling) is popular in soups. *In [[Italy]], meatballs (named ''polpette'' {{IPA-it|polˈpette|}}, sing. ''polpetta'') are generally eaten as a main course or in a soup. The main ingredients of an Italian meatball are beef and/or pork and sometimes poultry or sausage, salt, black pepper, chopped garlic, olive oil, Romano cheese, eggs, [[bread crumbs]], and parsley, mixed and rolled by hand to a golf ball size. In the [[Abruzzo]] region of Italy, especially in the [[Province of Teramo]], the meatballs are typically the size of marbles and are called ''polpettine'' {{IPA-it|polpetˈtiːne|}}. *In the [[Netherlands]], meatballs are called ''gehaktbal'', and are often served with boiled potatoes and vegetables. They are usually made out of mixed beef and pork minced meat, eggs, onion and [[bread crumbs]]. *In [[Norway]], meatballs are called [[:nb:Kjøttboller]] (lit. "meat bowls"). ''Kjøttboller'' are often served with brown sauce, [[:nb:Kålstuing|kålstuing]], [[:nb:Tyttebær|tyttebær]] and potatoes. Kjøttkaker are similar to Kjøttboller, except by form. Kjøttboller are round, like the typical meatball, whereas Kjøttkaker or meat cakes are in a patty form, flattened out and a bit oval in shape. *In [[Poland]], they are called ''pulpety'' (from the Italian name) or ''klopsy'' (singular ''pulpet''; ''klops'', from German ''Klopse''), and ''pulpeciki'' ("little ''pulpety''"), and are usually served cooked with a variety of sauces (such as tomato or a kind of gravy thickened with flour, as well as forest mushroom sauce) with potatoes, rice or all sorts of ''[[kasza]]''. ''Pulpety'' or ''klopsy'' are usually made from seasoned ground meat with onion and mixed with eggs and either breadcrumbs or wheat rolls soaked in milk or water. Fried ''pulpety'' are larger than typical cooked ones. They can be round or flat in shape. The latter, in many countries, would be considered a cross between a meatball and a hamburger. The fried variety is called ''mielony'' (short for ''kotlet mielony'', literally "minced cutlet"), and its mass-produced version (as well as the one served in bars, etc.) is the subject of many jokes and urban legends about what is used to produce it. *In [[Portugal]], meatballs are called ''almôndegas'' {{IPA-pt|aɫˈmõdɨɣɐʃ|}}. These are usually served with tomato sauce and pasta. *In [[Romania]] and [[Moldova]], meatballs are called ''[[chiftele]]'' or ''[[pârjoale]]'' and are usually deep fried and made with pork or poultry, moistened [[mashed potato]]es and spices. ''[[Chiftele]]'' are flat and round and contain more meat. A variant mixing rice inside the meatball is used for sour soup, making ''[[ciorbă de perişoare]]''. *In [[Russia]], they are called kotlety ({{lang-rus|котлеты}}) in flat forms or tefteli ({{lang-rus|тефтели}}) in ball forms. They can be made with chicken, pork, beef or fish. Tefteli have rice, potatoes and other vegetables mixed in as well. (Kotlety is only meat... with spice.) They can be served with a side of mashed potatoes or noodles, or in a sauce. *In [[Slovenia]], they are called polpeti. They are typically made with ground beef or a mixture of pork and beef and served with mashed potatoes, with tomato based sauce. *In [[Spain]] and [[Hispanic America]], meatballs are called ''albóndigas'', derived from the [[Arabic]] ''al-bunduq'' (meaning hazelnut, or, by extension, a small round object). ''Albóndigas'' are thought to have originated as a Berber or Arab dish imported to Spain during the period of [[Al-Andalus|Muslim rule]]. Spanish ''albóndigas'' can be served as an appetizer or main course, often in a tomato sauce. Mexican ''albóndigas'' are commonly served in a soup with a light broth and vegetables. *In {{anchor|Swedish meatball}} [[Swedish cuisine|Sweden]], ''köttbullar'' {{IPA-sv|ˈɕœtːbɵlar|}} are even often referred to as "köttbullar" Meatballs come in a few different types, all typically small, and the international influence is great, perhaps the greatest from Sweden and Spain. They are usually eaten with [[potato]]es or [[pasta]]. Some common additions are various vegetables, ketchup, various spices, etc. are made with ground beef or a mix of ground beef, pork and sometimes [[veal]] or [[venison]], sometimes including breadcrumbs soaked in milk, finely chopped (fried) onions, some broth and often including cream. They are seasoned with [[white pepper]] or [[allspice]] and [[salt]].<ref name="SE">Widenfelt, Sam ''Swedish Food'', Gothenburg, Sweden Esselte 1956.</ref><ref name=meatball>{{cite news |title=Köttbullar |url=https://sweden.se/culture-traditions/classic-swedish-food-meatballs/ |work=Sweden.se |date=January 1, 2018 }}</ref> Swedish meatballs are traditionally served with gravy, boiled potatoes, [[lingonberry jam]], and sometimes [[pickled cucumber]].<ref name="SE" /> Traditionally, they are small, around {{convert|2-3|cm|in}} in diameter although larger meatballs are often served at restaurants.<ref>Herbst, Sharon Tyler ''Food Lover's Companion'' Hauppauge, New York: Barron's Educational Series, Inc. 1990.</ref> In 2018 a Swedish twitter account claimed that what we know as Swedish meatballs are based on a Turkish recipe.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2018/may/03/my-whole-life-has-been-a-lie-sweden-admits-meatballs-are-turkish |title='My whole life has been a lie': Sweden admits meatballs are Turkish |first= Jon |last= Henley | publisher=[[TheGuardian.com]]|date= 3 May 2018 |accessdate=4 May 2018}}</ref> This statement has later been debunked by Swedish ethnologists.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.svd.se/forskare-sagar-varldsnyhet-om-kottbullar-fabricerat |title='Forskare sågar världsnyhet om köttbullar: ”Fabricerat”'| publisher=[[svd.se]]|date= 3 May 2018 |accessdate=4 May 2018}}</ref> *In the [[United Kingdom]], [[faggot (food)|faggots]] are a type of spicy [[pork]] meatball. A faggot is traditionally made from pig's heart, liver and fatty belly meat or bacon minced together, with herbs added for flavoring, and sometimes bread crumbs.
=== Americas === [[File:Meatball pizza.jpg|thumb|upright|A [[meatball pizza]]]] [[File:Albondigas en Chipotle.jpg|thumbnail|[[Mexican cuisine|Mexican]] albóndigas al chipotle]] Most meatball recipes found in Americas are derived from European cuisine influences, notably Italian, Iberian (Portuguese-Spanish), and Nordic (Swedish-Finnish) cuisines. *In [[Brazil]], meatballs are called ''almôndegas'', derived from [[Italy|Italian]] influences. These are usually served with tomato sauce and pasta. *In the [[Canada|Canadian]] province of [[Quebec]], meatballs are the main component of a traditional dish called ''ragoût de boulettes'' (meatballs stew). The meatballs are made with ground pork, onions, spices like cinnamon, cloves and nutmeg and are simmered in a gravy that's thickened with toasted flour. The dish is normally served with boiled or mashed potatoes and pickled beets. It is so popular that a factory-processed version of the dish is available canned in most supermarkets throughout the province. *In [[Mexico]], ''albóndigas'' are commonly served with a light broth and vegetables, or with a mild chipotle sauce. *In the [[United States]], meatballs are commonly derived from European cuisine influence. Usually, they are served with [[spaghetti]], on [[pizza]], or on a [[submarine sandwich|sub]], as in [[spaghetti and meatballs]], [[meatball pizza]], and [[meatball sandwich]]. In the southern United States, venison or beef is also often mixed with spices and baked into large meatballs that can be served as an entree. Another variation, called "porcupine meatballs" are basic meatballs often with rice in them.
=== Middle East and South Asia === {{Main article|Kofta}} [[File:Koofteh tabrizi.jpg|thumb|''Kofta'' (''Kufteh'' [[Tabriz]]i)]] ''Kofta'' is a type of meatball or [[dumpling]] that is widely distributed in [[Middle East]]ern, [[South Asian]], [[Mediterranean]] and Balkan (Central and Eastern Europe) cuisines. The word ''kofta'' is derived from [[Persian language|Persian]] ''kūfta'': In Persian, کوفتن (kuftan) means "to beat" or "to grind" or ''meatball''.<ref>Alan S. Kaye, "Persian loanwords in English", ''English Today'' '''20''':20-24 (2004), {{DOI|10.1017/S0266078404004043}}.</ref> In the simplest form, koftas consist of balls or fingers of minced or [[ground meat]] – usually [[beef]] or [[Lamb and mutton|lamb]] – mixed with spices and/or onions and other ingredients. The vegetarian variety is popular in India. They can be grilled, fried, steamed, poached, baked or marinated, and may be served with a rich spicy sauce.
*In [[Afghanistan]], meatballs are used as a traditional dish with homemade soups or are made with a tomato-based sauce that may include some plum seeds to increase tartness and is served with bread or rice which is called ''Kofta-Chelou''. Nowadays meatballs are also grilled on top of [[pizza]]. *In [[Iran]], several types of meatballs are consumed. If they are cooked in a stew, they are called ''kufteh.'' If they are fried (typically small meatballs), they are called ''kal-e gonjeshki'' (literally "[[sparrow]]'s head"). Both types are consumed with either bread or rice. Typically, herbs are added, and for ''kufteh'', usually the meatball is filled with hard boiled eggs or dried fruits. There are several (at least 10) types; the most famous is "kufteh tabrizi", traditionally from [[Tabriz]] in northwestern Iran. *In [[Israel]], meatballs are called ktzitzot basar ({{lang-he|קציצות בשר}}), or sometimes simply ktzitzot ({{lang-he|קציצות}}). Their exact ingredients and preparation vary widely, due to the influence of Jewish immigration from different regions. They are typically made of spiced ground beef, though turkey and chicken versions are also available, and in their common form, they are shaped as slightly flattened balls, pan fried and then cooked in tomato sauce or broth. Other variations also exist, including the [[Gondi (dumpling)|gondi]], which were brought by the [[Persian Jews]], the albondigas of the [[Sephardic cuisine]], and the kufta that is customary with some [[Mizrahi Jews]]. *In [[Pakistan]] and [[India]], meatballs are called ''koftas''. Pakistani & Indian meatballs are normally cooked in a spicy curry and sometimes with whole pre-boiled eggs. In Pakistan they are cooked in a gravy called ''chorba.'' Sometimes the eggs are encased in a layer of the spicy kofta meat so that the final product resembles an Indian [[Scotch egg]]. These kofta dishes are very popular with Indian diaspora and are widely available from many Indian restaurants. *In [[Syria]], meatballs are prepared in numerous ways. They are grilled on charcoal with or without eggplants or cooked in a stew with potato, onion and tomato sauce with a side of rice which is called Dawood Pasha. *In [[Turkish cuisine|Turkey]], meatballs are called [[köfte]] and are extremely popular, there are many different versions with a variety of shapes – not necessarily round. Meatballs in Turkey are usually made with ground lamb or a mix of ground beef and lamb. Some of the most popular ones are [[İnegöl köfte]], [[İzmir köfte]], [[Tire meatballs|Tire köfte]], [[şiş köfte]], [[kadınbudu köfte]], [[sulu köfte]], and [[Akçaabat meatballs|Akçaabat köftesi]]. *In [[West Bengal]] state of India and [[Bangladesh]], koftas are made with prawns, fish, green bananas, and cabbage, as well as minced goat meat.
=== East and Southeast Asia === [[File:Chinese meatballs 2.jpg|thumb|A variety of Chinese meatballs and [[fishball]]s]] *[[Chinese cuisine|Chinese]] meatballs (''wanzi'') are typically made of pork and can be steamed, boiled or deep fried, sometimes with the addition of [[soy sauce]]. Large meatballs, called [[lion's head (food)|lion's heads]], can range in size from about {{convert|5-10|cm|in|abbr=on}} in diameter. Smaller varieties, called [[pork ball]]s, are used in soups. A [[Cantonese cuisine|Cantonese]] variant, the [[steamed meatball]], is made of beef and served as a [[dim sum]] dish. Fish and seafood can also used to create different flavors and textures, and vegetarian alternatives to meatballs are served during festivals. In northern China, meatballs made from minced meat and flour, sometimes with the addition of [[lotus root]] or [[water chestnut]] for texture, are deep-fried and served in a [[vinegar]]-based sweet and sour sauce, or in a light broth with chopped [[coriander]]. [[File:Bakso.jpg|thumb|Indonesian ''[[bakso]]'' noodle soup]] *[[Indonesia]]n meatballs are called ''[[bakso]]'' which are usually served in a bowl, served in broth soup, with noodles, rice vermicelli, bean curd (tofu), hard-boiled egg, ''siomay''/ steamed meat dumpling, and fried wonton. They have a consistent homogeneous texture. ''Bakso'' can be found in major Indonesian cities and towns, however, the most popular are ''bakso Solo'' and ''bakso Malang'' (named after the city of origin). In Malang, ''bakso bakar'' (roasted ''bakso'') is also popular. As most Indonesians are Muslim, generally it is made from beef or sometimes chicken. *In [[Japanese cuisine]], a popular variant of meatballs is ''[[tsukune]]'', minced chicken meatballs on a skewer. The [[Japan]]ese [[hamburger]] steak, ''hanbāgu'', is typically made of ground beef, milk-soaked [[panko]] (bread crumbs) and minced, sauteed onions. They are typically eaten with a sauce made from ketchup and [[Worcestershire sauce]]. Chinese style meatballs are also popular. *In the [[Philippines]], meatballs are called ''almondigas'' or ''bola-bola'' and are usually served in a ''[[misua]]'' noodle soup with toasted garlic, squash and pork [[Pork rind|cracklings]]. ''Almondigas'' are derived from Hispanic influence on Filipino cuisine and ultimately derived from Moorish influence. Bola-bolas are also stewed or pan-fried until golden brown. Bola-bola is also used as a filling for [[siopao]], the local variant of [[baozi]]. *In [[Vietnam]], meatballs (''thịt viên'' hay ''mọc'', ''bò viên'', ''cá viên'') can be used as an ingredient in ''[[phở]]'' and ''[[hủ tiếu]]''. It is also common to cook meatballs in tomato sauce, and finely chopped spring onion and peppers are added before serving. In ''[[bún chả]]'' (a specialty Vietnamese rice noodle), meatballs are grilled to be ''chả'' and served with ''bún'' (rice noodles) and dipping sauce (based on fish sauce seasoned with rice vinegar, sugar, garlic, and chili). ''Xíu Mại'' is a pork meatball in a tomato sauce often served with a baguette.
<gallery class="center" caption="" widths="220px" heights="160px"> File:Seseri and Tsukune.jpg|Japanese ''Seseri'' (left) and {{Nihongo|[[Tsukune]]|つくね}} (right) File:Miswajf7582.JPG|Bola-bola with [[misua]] from the [[Philippines]] File:Bun Moc Ha Noi.jpg|A bowl of ''[[Bún mọc]]'' in [[Vietnam]], ''bún'' is rice vermicelli, while ''mọc'' means pork-ball </gallery>
== See also == {{portal|Food}} * [[Frikandel]], a Belgian and Dutch snack, similar in texture to meatballs, but shaped more like a hot dog or sausage than a ball * [[List of meatball dishes]] * [[Rissole]]

[[File:NBA League Pass (2010 Logo).jpg|right|thumb|NBA League Pass logo]]
The '''NBA League Pass''' is a [[sports television]] service that features all [[National Basketball Association]] games. The service is operated by [[Turner Broadcasting System]] on behalf of the NBA. It was made available prior to the start of the 1995-1996 NBA season. It is available to viewers in the [[United States]] and as an international package for all other countries. The pricing structure and services on offer are different, depending on where the viewer is located. The 2013-14 season was the 20th year of League Pass.<ref name="auto">Whitaker, Lang. blogs.nba.com "[http://allball.blogs.nba.com/2013/10/02/new-nba-league-pass-features-announced/ New NBA League Pass Features Announced]". Accessed 5th October 2013</ref> Full League Pass access for the 2014-15 season was priced at $199 for US customers, for comparison the premium service was £169.99 for UK viewers (these prices are for access to the full season prior to the first game and before any discounts, in previous seasons prices have dropped as the season moves closer towards the play-offs).<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://watch.nba.com/nba/subscribe|title = Subscription - NBA Game Time|date = 8 August 2014|accessdate = 8 August 2014|website = nba,com|publisher = |last = |first = }}</ref>
==United States League Pass==
'''NBA League Pass''' is an [[out-of-market sports package]] that allows its subscribers to watch up to 40 out-of-market [[National Basketball Association]] games a week. Videos of the games come from local stations and [[regional sports networks]].
League Pass comes in three varieties in the United States: '''NBA League Pass TV''', which plays the games through a cable or satellite TV provider; '''NBA League Pass Broadband''', which uses [[broadband|highspeed]] [[Internet]] connection to stream videos to a computer; and '''NBA League Pass Mobile''', which is for mobile devices.
Customers outside the United States can sign up for '''NBA International League Pass'''.
===Blackout restrictions=== {{see also|Blackout_(broadcasting)#NBA_blackout_policy|l1=NBA blackout policy}}
If a local team is playing and the game is televised in the home market, the associated feed on League Pass is blacked out and unavailable for viewing.
Per the NBA.com website: “Games will also be blacked out when they are appearing on national television. This applies to games being televised on ABC, ESPN, TNT and NBA TV. You may view these games simply by switching to the designated channel.”
In Canada, Bulls games on [[WGN-TV]] are not blacked out.
===NBA League Pass availability in the US=== NBA League Pass TV is available with these cable, satellite and streaming providers in the United States:
* ''United States'': ** [[AT&T U-verse]] ** [[DIRECTV]] ** [[Dish Network]] ** [[fuboTV]] ** [[In Demand|iN DEMAND Team]] *** [[Adams Cable]] *** [[Blue Ridge Communications]] *** [[Cablevision]] ([[Optimum TV]]) *** [[Comcast]] ([[Xfinity]]) *** [[Cox Communications]] *** [[Frontier Communications]] *** [[RCN Corporation|RCN]] *** [[Time Warner Cable]] *** [[Verizon FiOS]] ** [[Sling TV]]
Most providers who offer subscriptions to League Pass TV also include [[NBA TV]] and a companion League Pass Broadband subscription. It is also included in some cable subscriptions.
==NBA International League Pass==
NBA International League Pass is available to users living outside the United States, and differs from the US version of the product in its content, packaging, and pricing. While both the US and international products feature games available for live or on-demand viewing, the major distinction between the two products is that International League Pass provides access to all NBA games played during the regular season, All Star Weekend, Playoffs, and Finals, free from blackout restrictions. The single exception to this offering is in Canada, where games televised nationally are blacked out live and are available for on-demand viewing only after the game is completed.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://support.watch.nba.com/ViewArticle.dbml?SPSID=704416&SPID=118008&DB_OEM_ID=29500&ATCLID=205736022|title=NBAILP Support|accessdate=23 March 2015|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141101203056/http://support.watch.nba.com/ViewArticle.dbml?SPSID=704416&SPID=118008&DB_OEM_ID=29500&ATCLID=205736022|archivedate=1 November 2014|df=}}</ref> International League Pass also provides access to games from previous seasons through archives.<ref>watch.NBA.com - [http://watch.nba.com/nba/subscribe Subscription: NBA GAME TIME]. Accessed March 23, 2015 (note: accessed from an Australian IP. The page will differ by region).</ref>
International users have the option of subscribing to one of two packages: NBA League Pass and NBA League Pass Premium. Subscribers to both packages are able to watch all NBA games from the regular season, All Star Weekend, Playoffs, and Finals live or on-demand from a variety of devices, including desktop computers, iPhones, iPads, Android phones and tablets, and TV-connected devices like Apple TV, Google Chromecast, Xbox and PlayStation consoles (the platforms supported differ by country).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://support.watch.nba.com/SportSelect.dbml?&DB_OEM_ID=29500&SPID=118008&SPSID=704415|title=NBAILP Support|accessdate=23 March 2015}}</ref> Subscribers to both packages are also able to use in-game features including multi-game viewing, stats windows, and a condensed game feature that only includes scoring and highlight plays. Subscribers to the Premium package gain additional features, including access to a live stream of NBA TV International, additional NBA VOD content in the "Video Vault" including TNT's Overtime studio show, Spanish language feeds for certain games, and the option to choose between the broadcasts of the home or away team.
Beginning in the 2014-15 season, NBA International League Pass introduced continuous game feeds for selected games and all home feeds, which replaced the game break videos (highlights, commercials, etc.) shown during play breaks with highlight clips, live footage of in-arena activities including dance team performances, half-time entertainment, fans in the crowd, and interviews or features produced by the local broadcaster. Included with this footage is a statistics feed providing stats updates from around the league.
===International Packages and Promotions===
In addition to the standard and Premium packages, users also have the option to purchase a stand-alone streaming subscription to NBA TV International, which broadcasts games, studio shows, press conferences, and other basketball content.<ref>{{cite web|url= http://watch.nba.com/nba/live|title=NBA TV Live|accessdate=23 March 2015}}</ref> In past seasons, International League Pass has also offered sampling packages that provide stand-alone access to Christmas Day games and All Star Weekend events. The last several weeks of the regular season have also been made available in a separate "Race to the Playoffs" package.
During the off-season, both International League Pass and International League Pass Premium subscribers have live and on-demand access to Summer League games and certain games or scrimmages played by the USA Basketball team in preparation for or during the [[Olympics]] and the [[FIBA World Cup]] tournament, in addition to continued access to past NBA regular seasons in archives. This summer content has also been sold as a stand-alone package.
During the 2014-15 season, International League Pass offered a free trial of the product during the first week of the regular season and at the halfway point of the regular season, and other promotional free previews have been made available at various points in the season.
===NBA League Pass availability outside the US===
Note: Subscriptions can be bought in most regions via the Internet to be streamed to applications on various devices or to a browser (see above for list). Some of the following services include League Pass, either fully or partially, but they are not required to view League Pass.
*''Brazil'' **[[SKY Brasil]] * ''Canada'': ** [[Bell TV]] ** [[Shaw Direct]] ** [[Cogeco|Cogeco Cable]] ** [[EastLink (company)|EastLink Cable]] ** [[Rogers Cable]] *''Mexico and Central America'': ** [[SKY México]] *''Philippines'': ** [[Cablelink]], [[Globe Telecom|Globe]], [[Sky Cable]], and [[PLDT]]/[[Smart Communications|Smart]] *''South America and Caribbean (except Brazil)'': ** [[DirecTV]] *''United Kingdom'': ** [[BT Sport]]
==Applications, Features and Platforms supported==
Apps are currently available for:
* Smart TVs (depends on manufacturer/model) * [[Apple TV]] * [[Xbox 360]] * Android devices * [[iOS]] devices * [[Windows Phone]] * [[Roku]] * [[Amazon Kindle Fire]] * [[PlayStation 4]]<ref>[http://www.playstation.com/en-us/explore/playstationnetwork/entertainment/nba-gametime/ NBA Game Time], blog.playstation.com</ref>
For the 2013-14 season, League Pass's apps were updated with the ability to select home and away feeds on all games, and video-on-demand access for games broadcast nationally.<ref name="auto"/><ref>Pollakoff, Brett. "[http://probasketballtalk.nbcsports.com/2013/10/02/nba-makes-new-league-pass-features-official-all-nationally-televised-games-now-archived/ NBA makes new League Pass features official, all nationally televised games now archived]". ''Pro Basketball Talk'' (NBC Sports). Accessed October 5, 2013</ref>
For the 2016-17 season, a new feature known as "Mobile View" was introduced, which allows viewers to access a special feed of the home telecast with optimizations for viewing on smartphones. The Mobile View feed will utilize a new dedicated camera angle with a tighter, zoomed-in shot of gameplay. The league will provide a camera and a producer for the feature at each regular-season game, who will have access to the special camera and all others in use for the production.<ref name="svg-mobileview">{{cite web|title=NBA Installs Extra Camera, Adds Dedicated Producer to Each Game for New ‘NBA Mobile View’ Feature|url=http://www.sportsvideo.org/2016/10/24/nba-installs-extra-camera-adds-dedicated-producer-to-every-game-for-new-nba-mobile-view-streaming-feature/|website=Sports Video Group|accessdate=25 October 2016}}</ref><ref name="techcrunch-mobilefriendly">{{cite web|title=NBA League Pass is launching Mobile View to make it more enjoyable to watch games on your phone|url=https://techcrunch.com/2016/10/24/nba-league-pass-is-launching-mobile-view-to-make-it-more-enjoyable-to-watch-games-on-your-phone/|website=TechCrunch|publisher=AOL|accessdate=25 October 2016}}</ref>
==WNBA Season Pass== [[File:WNBA Season Pass.jpg|right|thumb|200px|Former WNBA Season Pass logo]] From 1999 to 2001, NBA League Pass had a companion service called '''WNBA Season Pass''' which showed out-of-market games of the [[Women's National Basketball Association]]. The WNBA has discontinued this service; today, all national broadcasts are on [[ESPN on ABC|ABC]], [[ESPN2]], or [[NBA TV]]. However, they now offer the '''WNBA Broadband Season Pass''', a web program that allows subscribers to watch every game live for each season.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.wnba.com/broadband/bsp_info.html|title=WNBA.com: WNBA Broadband Season Pass Info|author=|date=|website=www.wnba.com|accessdate=8 April 2018}}</ref>
==Summer League Pass==
The [[2013 NBA Summer League]] was available as a streaming subscription service with an app' for [[IOS]] and [[Android (operating system)|Android]] devices in the 2013 off-season. Priced at $14.99, all 61 games<ref>nba.com "[http://www.nba.com/bucks/news/john-henson-named-2013-all-nba-summer-league-team John Henson Named to 2013 All-NBA Summer League Team]". Accessed: October 2nd 2013.</ref> in both the [[Orlando Pro Summer League]] and the [[2013 NBA Summer League|Las Vegas League]] were included in the price.<ref>NBA.com. "[http://www.nba.com/2013/news/07/01/nba-tv-summer-league-schedule-release-2013/index.html NBA TV to televise 62 Summer League games, title game]". Accessed; October 2nd, 2013.</ref>

{{See also|Index of Argentina-related articles}} {{double image|right|Flag of Argentina.svg|196|Coat_of_arms_of_Argentina.svg|89|The [[Flag of Argentina]]|The [[Coat of arms of Argentina]]}} [[File:Argentina (orthographic projection).svg|right|188px]] [[Image:Argentinamap3.gif|thumb|An enlargeable map of the [[Argentine Republic]]]] The following [[Outline (list)|outline]] is provided as an overview of, and introduction to Argentina: '''[[Argentina]]''' – country in [[South America]], the continent's second largest by land area, after [[Brazil]]. It is constituted as a [[Federalism|federation]] of 23 [[Provinces of Argentina|provinces]] and an [[autonomous city]], Buenos Aires. It is the [[List of countries and outlying territories by total area|eighth]]-largest country in the world by land area and the largest among [[Hispanophone|Spanish-speaking nations]]. {{TOC limit|limit=2}} == General reference == [[image:Argentina-CIA WFB Map.png|thumb|An enlargeable basic map of [[Argentina]]]] * [[International Phonetic Alphabet|Pronunciation]]: {{IPAc-en|audio=en-us-Argentina.ogg|ˌ|ɑr|dʒ|ən|ˈ|t|iː|n|ə}} * Common English country name: [[Argentina]] * Official English country name: The [[Argentine Republic]] * Common [[endonym]](s): [[List of countries and capitals in native languages|Argentina]] * Official endonym(s): [[List of official endonyms of present-day nations and states|República Argentina]] * [[List of adjectival and demonymic forms of place names#Countries and nations|Adjectival]](s): [[Argentine (disambiguation)|Argentine]] * [[List of adjectival and demonymic forms of place names#Countries and nations|Demonym]](s): * [[Etymology]]: [[Name of Argentina]] * [[International rankings of Argentina]] * [[ISO country codes]]: AR, ARG, 032 * [[ISO region codes]]: See [[ISO 3166-2:AR]] * [[Internet]] [[country code top-level domain]]: [[.ar]] == Geography of Argentina == [[Image:Argentina topo blank.jpg|thumb|An enlargeable topographic map of [[Argentina]].]] [[Geography of Argentina]] * Argentina is a: [[Country]] * Location: ** [[Southern Hemisphere]] ** [[Western Hemisphere]] *** [[Latin America]] **** [[South America]] ***** [[Southern Cone]] ** [[Time zone]]: *** [[Argentina Time]] - ([[UTC-03]]) - No DST ** [[Extreme points of Argentina]] *** High: [[Aconcagua]] {{convert|6960|m|ft|0|abbr=on}} – highest point outside of [[Asia]] *** Low: [[Laguna del Carbón]] {{convert|-105|m|ft|0|abbr=on}} – lowest point in the [[Western Hemisphere]] and the [[Southern Hemisphere]] ** Land boundaries: 9,861 km ::{{Flag|Chile}} 5,308 km ::{{Flag|Paraguay}} 1,880 km ::{{Flag|Brazil}} 1,261 km ::{{Flag|Bolivia}} 832 km ::{{Flag|Uruguay}} 580 km :* Coastline: 4,989 km * [[Population of Argentina]]: 40,677,348 people (2008 [[Approximation|estimate]]) - [[List of countries by population|30th most populous country]] * [[Area of Argentina]]: {{convert|2766890|km2|abbr=on}} - [[List of countries and outlying territories by total area|8th largest country]] * [[:commons:Atlas of Argentina|Atlas of Argentina]] === Environment of Argentina === [[Image:Argentina Blue Marble.png|thumb|An enlargeable satellite image of the [[Argentina]]]] [[Environment of Argentina]] * [[Climate of Argentina]] * [[Renewable energy in Argentina]] * Geology of Argentina ** [[List of earthquakes in Argentina|Earthquakes in Argentina]] * [[Protected areas of Argentina]] ** [[List of biosphere reserves in Argentina|Biosphere reserves in Argentina]] ** [[List of national parks of Argentina|National parks of Argentina]] * [[Wildlife of Argentina]] ** [[Environment of Argentina#Flora|Flora of Argentina]] ** [[Environment of Argentina#Fauna|Fauna of Argentina]] *** [[List of birds of Argentina|Birds of Argentina]] *** [[List of mammals of Argentina|Mammals of Argentina]] ==== Natural geographic features of Argentina ==== * [[Glaciers of Argentina]] * [[List of islands of Argentina|Islands of Argentina]] * [[List of lakes in Argentina|Lakes of Argentina]] * [[List of mountains of Argentina|Mountains of Argentina]] ** [[List of volcanoes in Argentina|Volcanoes in Argentina]] * [[List of rivers of Argentina|Rivers of Argentina]] * [[List of World Heritage Sites in the Americas#Argentina|World Heritage Sites in Argentina]] === Regions of Argentina === [[Regions of Argentina]] The [[provinces of Argentina]] are often grouped into six geographical regions. From North to South and West to East, these are: *'''[[Argentine Northwest]]''': [[Jujuy Province|Jujuy]], [[Salta Province|Salta]], [[Tucumán Province|Tucumán]], [[Catamarca Province|Catamarca]], [[La Rioja Province, Argentina|La Rioja]] *'''[[Gran Chaco]]''': [[Formosa Province|Formosa]], [[Chaco Province|Chaco]], [[Santiago del Estero Province|Santiago del Estero]] *'''[[Mesopotamia, Argentina|Mesopotamia]]''' (or '''Littoral'''): [[Misiones Province|Misiones]], [[Entre Ríos Province|Entre Ríos]], [[Corrientes Province|Corrientes]] *'''[[Cuyo, Argentina|Cuyo]]''': [[San Juan Province, Argentina|San Juan]], [[Mendoza Province|Mendoza]], [[San Luis Province|San Luis]] *'''[[Pampa]]s''': [[Córdoba Province, Argentina|Córdoba]], [[Santa Fe Province|Santa Fe]], [[La Pampa Province|La Pampa]], [[Buenos Aires Province|Buenos Aires]] *'''[[Patagonia]]''': [[Río Negro Province|Rio Negro]], [[Neuquén Province|Neuquén]], [[Chubut Province|Chubut]], [[Santa Cruz Province, Argentina|Santa Cruz]], [[Tierra del Fuego Province, Argentina|Tierra del Fuego]] * '''[[Argentine Antarctica]]''' ==== Administrative divisions of Argentina ==== =====Provinces===== [[Provinces of Argentina]] {| style="background:transparent;" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="0" |- valign="top" |style="width:370px; font-size:95%;"| *'''{{flag|Buenos Aires|name=Autonomous City of Buenos Aires}}'''{{smallsup|a}} *'''{{flag|Buenos Aires Province}}''' *'''{{flag|Catamarca}}''' *'''{{flag|Chaco}}''' *'''{{flag|Chubut}}''' *'''{{flag|Córdoba}}''' *'''{{flag|Corrientes}}''' *'''{{flag|Entre Ríos}}''' *'''{{flag|Formosa}}''' *'''{{flag|Jujuy}}''' *'''{{flag|La Pampa}}''' *'''{{flagcountry|La Rioja (Argentina)}}''' *'''{{flag|Mendoza}}''' *'''{{flag|Misiones}}''' *'''{{flag|Neuquén}}''' *'''{{flagcountry|Río Negro (Argentina)}}'''{{smallsup|b}} *'''{{flag|Salta}}''' *'''{{flag|San Juan}}''' *'''{{flag|San Luis}}''' *'''{{flag|Santa Cruz}}''' *'''{{flag|Santa Fe}}''' *'''{{flag|Santiago del Estero}}''' *'''{{flag|Tierra del Fuego|name=Tierra del Fuego, Antártida e Islas del Atlántico Sur}}'''{{smallsup|c}} *'''{{flag|Tucumán}}'''

page.title: Roman Catholic Diocese of Fort Portal

revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=March 2014}} {{Expand Italian|Diocesi di Fort Portal|date=February 2011}} {{Infobox diocese |jurisdiction = Diocese |name = Fort Portal |latin = Dioecesis Arcis Portal |country = {{flag|Uganda}} |metropolitan = [[Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Mbarara|Mbarara]] |rite = [[Latin Church|Latin Rite]] |cathedral = |cocathedral = |area_km2 = 9,553 |population = 1,486,000 |population_as_of = 2006 |catholics = 696,000 |catholics_percent= 46.8 |pope = {{Incumbent pope}} |bishop = [[Robert Muhiirwa]] |coadjutor = |auxiliary_bishops= [[Joseph Mugenyi Sabiiti]] }}
The '''Roman Catholic Diocese of Fort Portal''' ({{lang-la|Arcis Portal}}) is a [[diocese]] located in the city of [[Fort Portal]] in the [[Ecclesiastical province]] of [[Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Mbarara|Mbarara]] in [[Uganda]].
The Catholic Diocese of Fort Portal formerly belonging to Rwenzori Vicariate was erected on 2 July 1961, with Vincent Joseph McCauley CSC as its first bishop. He was succeeded in 1972 by Serapio Magambo who served the Diocese until 1991, when Paul Kalanda took over as the third Bishop of the Diocese. His successor, the current bishop, Robert Muhiirwa, was ordained and installed on 15 June 2003.
==Leadership== * [[Bishop]]s of Fort Portal (Roman rite) ** Robert Muhiirwa (since 2003.03.18)<ref>[http://www.catholic-hierarchy.org/bishop/bmuhi.html Robert Muhiirwa Appointed Bishop on 18 March 2003 & Ordained Bishop of Fort Portal Diocese on 15 June 2003]</ref> ** [[Paul Lokiru Kalanda]] (1991.06.17 – 2003.03.18) ** Serapio Bwemi Magambo (1972.11.16 – 1991.06.17) ** [[Vincent J. McCauley]], [[Congregation of Holy Cross|C.S.C.]] (1961.02.21 – 1972.11.16)
Robert Muhiirwa Akiiki
Born at Ibonde, Virika Parish, Fort Portal Diocese on 23 Oct. 1958, ordained a priest on 11 August 1985. Appointed Bishop of Fort Portal Diocese on 18 March 2003; consecrated and installed as Bishop of Fort Portal Diocese on 15 June 2003. Lokiru Paul Kalanda
Lokiru Paul Kalanda. Born at Buwunde, Masaka Diocese, on 24 Feb.1927, ordained priest on 21 Dec.1957. Appointed Bishop of Moroto on 29 Nov 1980. Consecrated Bishop on 22 March 1981. Appointed Bishop of Fort Portal on 28 April 1991, installed Bishop of Fort Portal on 3 Nov.1991. Retired on 15 June 2003 and appointed Apostolic Admini-strator of Lira Diocese on 2 Dec. till 9 July 2005.
Joseph Mugenyi Sabiti, Auxiliary, Bishop of Fort Portal Diocese
Joseph Sabiiti Mugenyi. Born at Nyansozi, Fort Portal Diocese on 8 May 1948. Ordained Priest on 1 June 1975. Appointed Auxiliary Bishop of Fort Portal on 30 Jan.1999, Consecrated Bishop at Virika on 24 April 1999.

revision.text:
'''Sampson''' was a [[Shire horse]] [[gelding]] [[foal]]ed in 1846 in Toddington Mills, [[Bedfordshire]], [[England]]. He was the tallest and heaviest [[horse]] ever recorded.
Sampson, owned by Thomas Cleaver, stood {{hands|21.2+1/2}} high by the time he was four years old, when he was renamed '''Mammoth'''.
His peak weight was estimated at {{convert|3360|lb|kg|0|abbr=on|lk=on}}.<ref name=Whitaker60>Whitaker ''The Horse'' p. 60</ref> He was [[gelding|gelded]] at approximately one and a half years old, and [[horse testicles|his testicles]] were already the size of [[Ball (association football)|soccer ball]]s.<ref>''Encyclopedia of the Horse'', Norris, Carlos R., 1998, p. 174.</ref>

[[European Tour 2013/2014 – Event 1|Bulgarian Open]], [[Asian Tour 2013/2014 – Event 1|Yixing Open]] and [[2013 Six-red World Championship|Six-red World Championship]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Calendar 2013/2014|url=http://www.worldsnooker.com/staticFiles/21/bc/0,,13165~179233,00.pdf|publisher=[[World Professional Billiards and Snooker Association]]|work=worldsnooker.com|accessdate=30 April 2013|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6HWIR5A59|archivedate=20 June 2013}}</ref> *{{note label|rev2|b|b}} Revision 2 was used for the seeding of the [[2013 Shanghai Masters|Shanghai Masters]] and [[2013 Indian Open|Indian Open]].<ref name="Seeding points">{{cite web|title=2013/14 Calendar|url=http://www.worldsnooker.com/page/Tournaments/FullCalendar|publisher=[[World Professional Billiards and Snooker Association]]|work=worldsnooker.com|accessdate=21 July 2013|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140219095838/http://www.worldsnooker.com/page/Tournaments/FullCalendar|archivedate=19 February 2014}}</ref> *{{note label|rev3|c|c}} Revision 3 was used for the seeding of the [[2013 International Championship|International Championship]].<ref name="Seeding points"/> *{{note label|rev4|d|d}} Revision 4 was used for the seeding of the [[2013 UK Championship (snooker)|UK Championship]].<ref name="Seeding points"/> *{{note label|rev5|e|e}} Revision 5 was used for the seeding of the [[2014 German Masters|German Masters]], the [[2014 World Open (snooker)|World Open]], the [[2014 Masters (snooker)|Masters]] and the [[2014 Snooker Shoot-Out|Snooker Shoot-Out]].<ref name="Seeding points"/> *{{note label|rev6|f|f}} Revision 6 was used for the seeding of the [[2014 Welsh Open (snooker)|Welsh Open]] and the [[2014 China Open (snooker)|China Open]].<ref name="Seeding points"/> *{{note label|rev7|g|g}} Revision 7 was used for the seeding of the [[2014 World Snooker Championship|World Championship]].<ref name="Seeding points"/> {{refend}}

'''Data Broadcast'''
JO33-BS-TDM1→JO23-BS-TDM1''[https://web.archive.org/web/20000920073937/http://www.stgiga.co.jp/info_2/CO_info/corp_info.htm 会社案内]''. St.GIGA. Archived on September 20, 2000. |owner = [[WOWOW]] |website = {{webarchive | url=https://web.archive.org/web/20030528034550/http://www.stgiga.co.jp | date=May 28, 2003 | title=StGIGA.co.jp}} }} {{nihongo|'''St.GIGA'''|セント・ギガ|Sento.GIGA|lead=yes}} was a [[satellite radio]] company that was formed as a subsidiary of [[satellite television]] company [[WOWOW]] and later became semi-independent, forming a [[keiretsu]] with its parent.Chan, Koko. ''[https://archive.is/20030529103308/http://www5d.biglobe.ne.jp/~chankoko/soundgiga.html St.GIGA Sound of the Earth]''. Via [[Internet Archive]]. Using the [[Broadcasting Satellite (Japanese)|BS]] network to broadcast [[digital radio]] via [[direct broadcast satellite]] as a test on November 30, 1990, St.GIGA became the world's first Satellite Digital Audio Broadcast Corporation.''[http://srad.jp/story/03/09/30/002224/ さよならセント・ギガ]''. SRAD.jp. September 30, 2003.Mamoru, Sakamoto. ''[http://www.aa.alpha-net.ne.jp/mamos/digital/pcm.html PCM音声放送デッドヒートのゆくえ（St.GIGA開局前夜] {{webarchive|url=https://www.webcitation.org/67LVL0OrY?url=http://www.aa.alpha-net.ne.jp/mamos/digital/pcm.html |date=May 1, 2012 }}''. Alpha-Net. October 2, 2003. Regular broadcasting began March 30, 1991, and by September 1, St.GIGA adopted the commercial-free concept proposed by producer Hiroshi Yokoi and began to charge a broadcasting subscription fee.{{cite web | url=http://stgiga.jp/gallery/g-2.htm | title=セント・ギガ ギャラリー ● スクリーン・ミューター | language=Japanese | archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/67LVLdrs2?url=http://stgiga.jp/gallery/g-2.htm | archivedate=May 1, 2012 | publisher=St.GIGA | accessdate=November 15, 2018}} Following a period of financial difficulties and as part of an agreement with [[Nintendo]], from between April 1995 and June 2000, St.GIGA broadcast digitally encoded video games to owners of [[Super Nintendo Entertainment System|Super Famicoms]] with the [[Satellaview]] attachment.Kameb. ''[http://www.f3.dion.ne.jp/~kameb/satella/st_prg/st_prg.htm スーパーファミコンアワー番組表] {{webarchive|url=https://www.webcitation.org/67LVML1fI?url=http://www.f3.dion.ne.jp/~kameb/satella/st_prg/st_prg.htm |date=May 1, 2012 }}'' The Satellaview History Museum. February 12, 2008. Satellaview broadcasts were limited in distribution to Japan alone,''[http://blogsimages.skynet.be/images_v2/002/525/891/20060417/dyn006_original_450_691_pjpeg_2525891_9beba3cbc16b52839c5403eccbfd840e.jpg Sega, Nintendo et la Télevision...] {{webarchive|url=https://archive.is/20120718074600/http://blogsimages.skynet.be/images_v2/002/525/891/20060417/dyn006_original_450_691_pjpeg_2525891_9beba3cbc16b52839c5403eccbfd840e.jpg |date=July 18, 2012 }}''. C+. p42. Retrieved March 1, 2009. however through St.GIGA's services Nintendo broadcast a large number of rare ''[[wikt:裏|ura]]'' and ''[[gaiden]]'' versions of some of its most popular franchises such as ''[[The Legend of Zelda (series)|The Legend of Zelda]]'', ''[[Mario]]'', and ''[[Kirby (series)|Kirby]]''.''[http://csd.varlew.net/satellaview.php Crash Course on the Satellaview System]''. Chrono Series Database. Retrieved March 1, 2009.''[http://console-news.dcemu.co.uk/30-great-gaming-world-records-184500.html 30 Great Gaming World Records]''. Console Hardware News. February 15, 2009.''[http://blogs.ign.com/Hyrule-Times/p3 Retrospective: BS Zelda]''. [[IGN]]. June 8, 2006.''[http://myweb.tiscali.co.uk/superfamicom/satellaview.html Super Famicom Central: Satellaview] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070114160603/http://myweb.tiscali.co.uk/superfamicom/satellaview.html |date=January 14, 2007 }}''. Super Famicom Central. Retrieved March 1, 2009. With the exception of ''[[BS Fire Emblem: Akaneia Senki]]'', these games have never been re-released and can only be played today via incomplete emulation.''[http://www.blamethecontrolpad.com/bsx/bsx2.htm Broadcast Satellaview - X] {{webarchive|url=https://www.webcitation.org/67LVULae4?url=http://www.blamethecontrolpad.com/bsx/bsx2.htm |date=May 1, 2012 }}''. BlameTheControlpad. Retrieved March 1, 2009. ==Satellite history== Broadcast between March 11, 1990 and November 28, 2007, St.GIGA has undergone a number of changes of both carrier satellite and broadcast band. The following is a condensed history of these changes:''[https://web.archive.org/web/20130227122523/http://www.stgiga.jp/history.htm セント・ギガの歴史]''. StGIGA.jp. Retrieved February 18, 2009. *April 2, 1990 - St.GIGA is founded.''[https://web.archive.org/web/20010726233007/http://www.nikkei.co.jp/news/sangyo/20010725CAHI052525.html BSラジオ放送のセント・ギガ、民事再生法申請]''. Nikkei New Media. July 26, 2001. *St.GIGA began broadcasts on BS-3ch in 1990 via the [[BS-2a]] satellite.''[https://web.archive.org/web/20080905163754/http://www.transmitter-frequencies.com/sat-6989.php Satellite Frequency from BSAT 1A,2A]''. Transmitter-Frequencies.com. Retrieved February 18, 2009. *August 1991 - St.GIGA switched to the [[BS-3b]] satellite, and in September it began broadcasting on BS-5ch *April 23, 1995 - Broadcasts begin to the [[Super Famicom]] add-on, [[Satellaview]]. *April 1999 - Nintendo withdraws support. *June 30, 2000 - Last Satellaview broadcast. *On December 1, 2000, St.GIGA began simultaneous broadcasts on Radio 333ch (Data broadcasting via 633 and 636ch)''[http://www.geocities.co.jp/WallStreet/4015/bsdatalist.html 衛星データ放送]''. 文字放送・データ放送・インタラクティブ放送. Retrieved November 24, 2014.[https://web.archive.org/web/20010212071824/http://www.stgiga.co.jp/DATA/data.htm セント・ギガ 衛星データ放送]. St.GIGA. Archived on February 12, 2001. *March 21, 2003 - St.GIGA becomes Club COSMO. *October 1, 2003 - Club COSMO sold to WINJ *2005 - Club COSMO's 5ch broadcasts became analog (March 31) and the switch to 333ch was completed (May 10) *2006 - WINJ begins St.GIGA rebroadcasts *On November 28, 2007 all affiliated broadcast bands are terminated and the satellite broadcast certificate is revoked. ==Concept== In 1990 the established Japanese [[satellite television]] company [[WOWOW]] decided to expand their services into the field of [[satellite radio]]. The core management team made the executive decision to create a subsidiary named St.GIGA. The name was selected by a popular poll of "[[Vox populi|persons on the streets]]" because the executives agreed that they knew nothing about music. In deciding whom to hire as director for the subsidiary, {{nihongo|Hiroshi Yokoi|横井宏}} (who had recently designed the successful [[J-Wave|J-Wave FM]]) was selected as an innovator in the field. Soon after accepting the position, Yokoi crafted a radical proposal for the station concept. The initial reaction at WOWOW was skeptical; however within a few months of traditional satellite radio broadcasts, Yokoi's concept was given probationary adoption, and Yokoi was subsequently given full discretion to shape the company's future. ===Yokoi's "Tide of Sound"=== Under Hiroshi Yokoi's direction, the St.GIGA station motto became "I'm here. — I'm glad you're there. — We are St.GIGA."''[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=IxX6rClbpR4 セントギガの例の台詞]''. St.GIGA. Retrieved February 18, 2009.''[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=s0VA2_gm5CA&feature=related 【BS-5ch】衛星デジタル音楽放送 St.GIGA　その１]'' St.GIGA. Retrieved February 18, 2009. This is a referenceMurasaki. ''[http://www2k.biglobe.ne.jp/~murasaki/St-GIGA/concept.htm Proguramming Concept]''. Retrieved February 15, 2009. to [[Kurt Vonnegut]]'s ''[[The Sirens of Titan]]'' in which the alien life forms called [[Harmonium (fictional creature)|harmoniums]] communicate using only the phrases "Here I am." and "So glad you are."[[Kurt Vonnegut|Vonnegut, Kurt]]. ''[[The Sirens of Titan]]''. Random House, Inc. 1959. p 189. 1998. {{ISBN|978-0-385-33349-8}} Strongly influenced by the works of Kurt Vonnegut and Kevin W. Kelley's ''The Home Planet'',''[http://www.thinktheearth.net/recommended/recommend.html Recommended]''. ThinkTheEarth. Retrieved February 18, 2009. Yokoi's original concept proposal for St.GIGA would break new ground for broadcast communication methodology. In accordance with Yokoi's conception, St.GIGA's broadcasts initially followed no externally fixed (or artificial) timetable. Rather they were based upon the cyclical motif of a 24-hour "[[tide table]]"Toop, David & Réveillon, Arnaud. ''[https://books.google.com/books?id=s1JNNhZGZFcC&pg=PA164&lpg=PA164 Ocean of Sound: ambient music, mondes imaginaires et voix de l'éther]''. Editions Kargo. Pp. 164-5. 2000. {{ISBN|2-84162-048-4}} where broadcast themes were approximately matched to the current tidal cycle according to the [[rule of twelfths]] throughout the 24-hour broadcasting period.''[http://www.stgiga.jp/gallery/g-3.htm セント・ギガ ギャラリー ● タイムテーブル]''. StGIGA.jp. May–December 1993.''[http://www2k.biglobe.ne.jp/~murasaki/image/voice8_t.JPG Colors of Seasons]''. St.GIGA. September 1, 1991.''[http://www.stgiga.jp/gallery/book-7.jpg 夢の潮流 -St.GIGA編成総論横井宏著 発行所]'' St.GIGA. Apdx 4. September 1991. Under this innovative schedule, the station broadcast a variety of primarily ambient music programs including {{nihongo|''Music Tide''|音楽潮流|Ongaku Chōryū}}, various jazz programs,''[http://stgiga.jp/mj061026-1.htm Midnight Jazz Hank De Mano Quartet 「in concert」他]''. StGIGA.jp. October 26, 2006.''[http://stgiga.jp/mj061026-2.htm Midnight Jazz - Judy Bailey Trio/Quintet 「My Favourite Things」 他]''. StGIGA.jp. October 26, 2006. and {{nihongo|''Tide Table''|タイド・テーブル|Taido . Teburu}} (featuring live sound-broadcasts of the ocean shore). The beginnings and ends of programs were not clearly demarcated and instead utilized the unprecedented {{nihongo|"Tide of Sound"|音の潮流|Oto no Chōryū}} method where songs of one genre would gradually flow into and intersperse with the songs from the prior genre until the new genre became predominant. The intent, according to Yokoi was to allow the listener to relax in a wave of sound "like a baby sleeps in the womb." "Tide of Sounds" broadcasts operated under a principle of "No [[Radio advertisement|Commercials]], No [[DJ]]s, No [[News|News Broadcasts]], No [[Talk radio|Talk]]." Unlike most commercial-driven radio broadcasts, this was made possible for St.GIGA due to its reliance on a subscription [[Digital Audio Broadcasting]] (DAB) service. In order to receive this DAB service, the subscriber was required to obtain a special decoder, to pay an initiation fee, and subsequent monthly fees.Valenti, Gregory. ''[http://heinonline.org/HOL/Page?collection=journals&handle=hein.journals/amuilr8&div=22&size=2&rot=0&type=image Digital Audio Broadcasting: An International Perspective on Compact-Disc Quality Radio]''. 8 [[Washington College of Law#Publications|Am. U. J. Int'l L. & Pol'y]] 273, 289, 295-7 (1992). "Tide of Sounds" broadcasts often took the form of high-quality digital recordings of [[biomusic|nature sounds]] accompanied by [[spoken word]] narration by an [[voice acting|actor]] as the "Voice."''[http://www2k.biglobe.ne.jp/~murasaki/image/voice8_b.JPG St.GIGA NEWS]''. St.GIGA. September 1, 1991. Throughout the life span of "Tide of Sounds" broadcasts, the part of the "Voice" would be played by a number of notable Japanese poets including Ryo Michiko among others.Michiko, Ryo. ''[http://ryomichico.net/bbs/voice.html Voice／寮美千子の詩]''. Retrieved February 19, 2009. "Voice" performances often consisted of all new poetry composed specifically for the show. St.GIGA also broadcast its B-mode audio programming (a series of all [[classical music]] broadcasts) over analog broadcasting frequency bands that were shared with its parent, the [[satellite television|satellite broadcasting]] company [[WOWOW]]. Highly artistic and experimental, the St.GIGA sound became extremely popular within certain segments of the population, and the station was recognized for its innovative concept, unique vision, and nonstandard methodology.''[http://www.soundbum.org/sekai/02komazawa.html INTERVIEW ： 音のある世界で MDと風鈴を持って、山へ Vol. 2 　駒沢敏器さん]''. SoundBum. November 25, 1998. Fan publications such as ''BSFan Journal'' and ''G-Mania'' sprang up to publish details of the music and to report on the ambient, mood, and electronic scene that was burgeoning in Japan.''[http://www2k.biglobe.ne.jp/~murasaki/St-GIGA/bsfan.htm ＢＳfan誌（共同通信社）連載記事]''. June 1992 - January 1993. To this day numerous fan groups, trading groups, and collectors with an emphasis on St.GIGA's musical products exist online.''[http://www.geocities.co.jp/NatureLand-Sky/7044 St.GIGA Soundstream Fan Club]''. Retrieved February 18, 2009. The initial popularity of the music funded trips by St.GIGA [[biomusic]] recorders to travel abroad to record at such exotic locations as [[England]], [[Canary Islands]], [[Mikonos]], [[Venice]], [[Bali]], [[Tahiti]], [[Martinique]], Hanson Island ([[British Columbia|BC]]), and [[Maui]].[http://www2k.biglobe.ne.jp/~murasaki/image/style_24.JPG St.GIGA CREW'S]. St.GIGA. p. 25-26. Retrieved February 18, 2009.Murasaki. ''[http://www2k.biglobe.ne.jp/~murasaki/St-GIGA/style.htm St.GIGA Stylebook]''. February 1, 2001.''St.GIGA stylebook''. Vol. 2, 1991. St.GIGA was also able to release a number of thematic books including the multi-volume ''St.GIGA Stylebook'', {{nihongo|''Current of dreams: An introduction St.GIGA programming''|Yume no choryu: St.Giga hensei soron}} (containing the full text of Yokoi's original concept proposal), and {{nihongo|''Trends in Dreaming - St.GIGA's Hiroshi Yokoi's General Office''|夢の潮流 -St.GIGA編成総論横井宏著 発行所}} (also released on VHS''[http://www.stgiga.jp/gallery/book-2.jpg 夢の潮流 -St.GIGA編成総論横井宏著 発行所]''. StGIGA.jp. October 28, 1991.). Later thematic films were sold including ''Traveling with St.GIGA'' (1999)''[http://yutakakawasaki.hp.infoseek.co.jp/info/2001.htm SPUTNIK SPACELINES／Tokyo Designers Block 2002　LIVE EVENT@SPUTNIK DOME]''. Tokyo Designers Block 2002. Retrieved March 1, 2009. and ''Sound and Vision'' (2007)Nishimura, Yoshiaki. ''[http://www.livingworld.net/essays/nish_061225 St.GIGA]''. LivingWorld.net. December 25, 2006. {{quote box | align=right | width=25% | quote=St. Giga and other satellite radio broadcasters found it hard to attract paying subscribers as Japan's recession made consumer reluctant to invest in the expensive antennas and tuners needed to pick up satellite broadcasts.| source=''Billboard Magazine'', July 23, 1994}} St.GIGA sold a variety of products ranging from program guides''[http://www.stgiga.jp/gallery/g-4.htm セント・ギガ ギャラリー - ● プログラムガイド]''. StGIGA.jp. Retrieved February 19, 2009. to "sound calendars"''[http://www.stgiga.jp/gallery/g-7.htm セント・ギガ ギャラリー - ● サウンドカレンダー]''. StGIGA.jp. Retrieved February 19, 2009. to fragrances.{{ cite web | url=http://www.stgiga.jp/gallery/g-8.htm | title=セント・ギガ ギャラリー - ● 地球の香り | deadurl=yes | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120220121209/http://www.stgiga.jp/gallery/g-8.htm | archivedate=February 20, 2012 | publisher=St.GIGA | accessdate=May 26, 2014}} The company also released a number of CDs under St.GIGA's own label as well as a variety of foreign labels such as the [[Hearts of Space]], and music by [[Deep Forest]].''[http://www2k.biglobe.ne.jp/~murasaki/image/voice12_b.JPG Quest for Saint]''. St.GIGA. 1993. The market for ambient music and its related forms was not as strong as initially anticipated, and demand was impacted by Japan's recession. By 1994, the station was beginning to face serious financial difficulties, resulting in drastic changes in programming. ==Satellite Data broadcasting== [[File:BSSuperMario.png|thumb|200px|right|Between April 23, 1995 and June 30, 2000, St.GIGA broadcast video game data for such games as ''[[BS Super Mario USA]]'' which were only playable with [[Nintendo]]'s [[Satellaview]] subsystem.]] {{main|Satellaview}} {{cquote |Nintendo expects to sell 2 million [Satellaview] adapter/cassette packages a year.}} {{quote box | align=right | width=25% | quote=Unlike St. Giga's regular programming, the new data service will feature paid advertising. Nintendo president Hiroshi Yamauchi [said] that Nintendo expects to sell 2 million adapter/cassette packages a year.| source=''Billboard Magazine'', July 23, 1994}} By 1994, St.GIGA's financial difficulties resulted in the cutting back of "Tide of Sound" broadcasts. The company's portion of the subscription-funded audio broadcasts were to be replaced under subcontract by an all new series of advertising-funded Satellite Data broadcasts, managed under the "rescue" and executive control of [[Nintendo]], St.GIGA's largest shareholder at 19.5%.{{ cite journal | last=McClure | first=Steve | title=Japan's St. Giga to broadcast Nintendo Games | work=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]] | volume=106 | number=30 | pages=78, 84 | date=July 23, 1994 | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=YAgEAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA78&dq=billboard+magazine+july+23,+1994 | accessdate=May 26, 2014}}Vedwa, Niraj. [http://www.nasscom.in/upload/34735/NirajVedwa_GlobalcompetitiveIT.ppt "Indian I.T. – Challenges for Global Competitiveness"]. IIFT-NASSCOM Seminar. December 13, 2004 Beginning on April 23, 1995, St.GIGA broadcast video-game-related data to owners of the [[Super Nintendo Entertainment System|Super Famicom]]'s [[Satellaview]]{{cite patent|US|6611957}}''[http://www.freepatentsonline.com/6611957.html Start Signal for a Computer Program in a Network Environment with Start Signal of Time Information, Program ID and CM Data]''. FreePatentsOnline.com. Retrieved February 18, 2009.''[http://www.google.com/patents?id=2BEPAAAAEBAJ&printsec=abstract#PPA1,M1 Technique for Executing a Software Program in Response to a Received Start]''. Google Patents. October 28, 2003.''スーパーファミコンアワーの可能性と未来''. Saterabyu Tsuushin. Vol. 5. 1995. peripheral created by [[Nintendo]]. This device bolts onto the underside of the Super Famicom''[http://myweb.tiscali.co.uk/superfamicom/satellaview.htmlSuper Famicom Central]''. Retrieved February 18, 2009. in a manner similar to the later [[Nintendo 64DD]]'s attachment to the [[Nintendo 64]] and the [[Game Boy Player]]'s attachment to the [[GameCube]]. Only released to the Japanese market, the Satellaview acted as a [[satellite modem]],''[http://www.gamersgraveyard.com/repository/snes/peripherals/satallaview.html Satallaview]'' The SNES Peripherals Index. Retrieved February 18, 2009. allowing players to download broadcast data. The resulting games were then stored on requisite specialized rewritable storage cartridges at an additional launch price of 14,000 yen ($143). The broadcast content ranged from video-game-related Satellaview news and specific interest journals such as {{nihongo|''Game Tiger's big House''|ゲーム虎の大穴|Gemu Tora no OoAna}} to expansion data for popular Super Famicom games (including, for example, ''[[Chrono Trigger#Related media|Chrono Trigger]]'') and all new video game releases including titles in such flagship series as ''[[BS Zelda|The Legend of Zelda]]'', ''[[Super Mario Bros. 2#BS Super Mario USA|Super Mario]]'', and ''[[Kirby (series)#History|Kirby]]''. Additionally, a number of these broadcasts featured an updated version of St.GIGA's earlier "Tide of Sounds" "Voice," now called {{nihongo|"[[Satellaview#SoundLink|SoundLink]]"|サウンドリンク}}, with which St.GIGA [[voice acting|voice actors]] would provide a live vocal track to accompany games, setting plot and describing in-game goals. Due to the rewritability of the cartridges, the fact that "SoundLink" broadcasts were not downloaded to the game cartridges but rather were streamed live during the noon-2AMSinhonggyun. ''[http://www.rapa.or.kr/korean/data/kdt01b1210sh.htm 한국전파 진흥협회]'' Korean Aerospace University. Retrieved February 19, 2009. ''Super Famicom Hour'' broadcasting time, and because the broadcast game data have never been rereleased by Nintendo, these games have become extremely rare. The subculture of collectors and enthusiasts that has grown online have exerted much effort engaged in electronic [[archaeology]] by extracting old data from heavily rewritten data cartridges in order to faithfully reproduce the games via emulation.''[http://board.zsnes.com/phpBB2/viewtopic.php?p=184890&sid=c97a28782289bd22e190bef4adddc12e bsnes v0.038 released]'' ZSNES Board. Retrieved February 18, 2009. Aside from St.GIGA's "SoundLink" or broadcasts accompanying the transmission of data for its {{nihongo|"Soundlink Games"|サウンドリンクゲーム}}, St.GIGA also broadcast a wealth of information on talk shows and celebrity idols, including a variety show. Broadcast times were fitted to match the schedules of students, and the station's audience demographics shifted radically much to the disappointment of the station's former ambient music fans. Before long the station had ceased transmissions of all "Time & Tide" programs (those featuring [[new age]] music) including the much-admired {{nihongo|''Tidal Currents''|潮の潮流|Shio no Chōryū}}, Fan publications such as ''BSFan Journal'' became replaced by more populist publications like {{nihongo|''[[Satellaview Tsūshin|Satellaview Communications Magazine]]''|サテラビュー通信|Saterabyu Tsuushin}},Kameb. ''[http://www.f3.dion.ne.jp/~kameb/satella/st_tushi/st_tushi.htm サテラビュー通信記事紹介]''. June 1995-May 1996. and St.GIGA focused all energies on Satellaview transmissions.''[http://www.asahi-net.or.jp/~vw6y-mk/v35/other/radio/radio.html I'm here. I'm glad you are there. - サヨナラSt.GIGA]''. Satellaview transmissions continued uninterruptedly with only a single recertification''[http://www.soumu.go.jp/joho_tsusin/pressrelease/english/mpt-news/vol10_8.pdf MPT’s Regular Personnel Changes]''. Biweekly Newsletter of the Ministry of Posts and Telecommunications, Japan. Vol. 10, No. 8. p.2. August 2, 1999. ISSN 0917-169X between 1995 and April 1999. Carrying a "cumulative debt of 8.8 billion yen" as of March 1998, a Reuters report on August 21, 1998 indicated St.GIGA's rejection of Nintendo's debt management proposal as well as the broadcaster's failure to apply for renewal of its governmental satellite license. This resulted in the withdrawal of Nintendo's five executive staff, and the withdrawal of all current and proposed programming plans by Nintendo, Kyocera, and "many content providers", that had been intended for launch in 2000; though Nintendo's 19.7% ownership portfolio remained intact. St.GIGA continued Satellaview broadcasts after this point; however, the company could only broadcast reruns of games previously transmitted as Nintendo had discontinued its supply of new original content as of March 1999. Facing economic difficulties again, St.GIGA discontinued its Satellaview broadcasts on June 30, 2000 in order to return focus to music broadcasts as had been done prior to the Nintendo deal.{{ cite web | url=http://belarus.8m.com/1/cnn060001.html | title=Nintendo drops satellite plan - Video-game company halts plan to deliver games directly to homes | publisher=Reuters | date=August 21, 1998 | accessdate=May 26, 2014}} ==Later years and current status== By 2001, St.GIGA was nearly bankrupt and entered into merger talks with {{nihongo|WireBee Inc.|株式会社ワイヤービー|Kabushikigaisha Waiyabi}} with which it became associated for the remainder of its lifespan.''[https://web.archive.org/web/20020619232027/http://nnm.nikkeibp.co.jp/nnm/2002/06/NNM20020610_193.html St.GIGA，民事再生手続きが終了，ディジタルBS放送専業で再出発]''. Nikkei New Media. June 10, 2002. On March 21, 2003, following the death by cancer of director Yokoi,Nagano, Doranka. ''[http://www.chartdrunker.info/archives/2007-05.html 第２２６回ランキング]''. May 25, 2007. St.GIGA was rechristened {{nihongo|Club COSMO|クラブコスモ|Kurabukosumo}} under the leadership of {{nihongo|Shinichi Matsuo|松尾信一}}. Broadcasts continued until October 1, when the company was forced to sell its licensing rights to World Independent Networks Japan Inc. (WINJ). WireBee immediately began bankruptcy procedures,Tadayuki, Mitani [http://www1.odn.ne.jp/~cjq24190/insolvent%20cases/24civil02.html 2-4(2)160 衛星デジタル音楽放送（株）]. The Mitani Tadayuki Law Office. January 18, 2010. and all recording instruments and 241 tapes of nature sounds were auctioned off at open market for a total divided sale price of ¥5 million. Discussions concerning Club COSMO's involvement under WINJ's oversight in a new reality show were circulated briefly at this time, however to date no such show has been produced. In 2006, WINJ began broadcasting reruns of St.GIGA's original "Tide of Sound" and "Time & Tide" broadcasts during a 2PM-4PM time slot,''[http://stgiga.jp/ttable/pdf.htm WINJタイムテーブル]''. StGIGA.jp. Retrieved February 20, 2009. however on November 1 of the same year these broadcasts were suspended on the pretext of broadcasting equipment maintenance. The program was scheduled to resume in the 2007 fiscal year, however on November 14, 2007, [[Hiroya Masuda]] the Minister of [[Ministry of Internal Affairs and Communications|Internal Affairs]] revoked the broadcasting certificate under Act 54 of Article 24 of the Japanese General Broadcasting Statute.Nihei, Shigeru. ''[http://law.e-gov.go.jp/htmldata/S25/S25HO132.html#1000000000000000000000000000000000000000000000005202400000002000000000000000000 放送法（昭和二十五年五月二日法律第百三十二号）]''. Retrieved February 18, 2009. ==See also== * [[Satellaview]] - The Nintendo peripheral that allowed player to download BS Games directly to its [[Super Nintendo Entertainment System|Super Famicoms]] * [[WOWOW]] - Parent [[satellite television|satellite broadcasting]] [[TV Station]]. * [[Broadcasting Satellite System Corporation]] - The company that controlled the satellites from which St.GIGA broadcast, and its current fleet of Japanese broadcasting satellites. ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} ==External links== * [http://stgiga.jp St.GIGA Forever - St.GIGA homepage] {{ja icon}} * [https://web.archive.org/web/*/http://www.stgiga.co.jp www.stgiga.co.jp at the Internet Archive] {{ja icon}} * [http://www.sensorium.org/sensingjapan/interview/kawasaki/profile/kawa_pro.html St.GIGA program director, Yoshihiro Kawasaki's personal website] {{ja icon}} * [[:ja:寮美千子|ja.wikipedia article on "Voice" performer Ryo Michiko]] {{ja icon}} * [http://ryomichico.net/bbs.html Harmonia - Ryo Michiko's personal website] {{ja icon}} * [https://web.archive.org/web/20110715045112/http://www.partialmusic.com/live/video_popup.php/Robert_Newcomb_Music_Resume.pdf?filename=dl_file&gallery=true&id=3&download=1&start_dl=1 "Tide of Sound" performer, Robert Newcomb's page] * [http://www2k.biglobe.ne.jp/~murasaki/St-GIGA.htm Revival of St.GIGA's "tidal sound"] {{ja icon}} {{Nintendo developers}} [[Category:DAB ensemble]] [[Category:Digital radio]] [[Category:Nintendo]] [[Category:Radio stations established in 1990]] [[Category:1990 establishments in Japan]] [[Category:Radio stations disestablished in 2007]] [[Category:2007 disestablishments in Japan]] [[Category:Defunct radio stations in Japan]] [[Category:Satellite radio stations]] [[Category:Super Nintendo Entertainment System]] [[Category:Defunct companies of Japan]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox book | name = The King Incorporated:
Leopold the Second in the age of trusts | image = File:TheKingIncorporated.jpg | caption = First edition | author = [[Neal Ascherson]] | title_orig = | translator = | illustrator = | cover_artist = | country = United Kingdom | language = English | series = | subject = | genre = | publisher = [[George Allen & Unwin]] | pub_date = 1963 | english_pub_date = | media_type = Print | pages = 310 | isbn = 1-86207-290-6 | oclc = | dewey = 923.1493 | congress = | preceded_by = | followed_by = The Polish August : the self-limiting revolution }} '''''The King Incorporated''''' was the first history book published by award-winning Scottish journalist and historian [[Neal Ascherson]] exploring the course of the [[Congo Free State]] from its foundation to annexation, as well as the role of [[King Leopold II]]. ''The King Incorporated'' was first published in 1963 (three years after the Congo's independence from Belgium) and has been reprinted in eight editions. The 1999 edition (published by [[Granta]]) modified the book's title to ''The King Incorporated: Leopold the Second and the Congo,'' omitting the reference to [[Trust (business)|trusts]]. ==Reception== The work was described by ''[[The Guardian]]'' as "a fascinating account of Leopold II of Belgium and his extraordinary attempt to integrate the rapacious exploitation of a personal colony with a version of 19th-century European kingship."{{cite journal|last=Wroe|first=Nicholas|title=Neal Ascherson: Romantic nationalist|journal=The Guardian|date=12 April 2003|url=https://www.theguardian.com/books/2003/apr/12/history.politics}} The celebrated British historian [[A.J.P. Taylor]] also praised the work.{{cite book|last=Ascherson|first=Neal|title=The King Incorporated|year=1999|publisher=Granta Books|pages=Cover}} ==References== {{reflist}} {{DEFAULTSORT:King Incorporated, The}} [[Category:1963 books]] [[Category:British biographies]] [[Category:History books about colonialism]] [[Category:Congo Free State]] [[Category:History books about the Belgian Congo]] [[Category:Books about Leopold II of Belgium]] [[Category:Works about the European colonisation in Africa]] {{Africa-hist-book-stub}} {{poli-bio-book-stub}}
